<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_probe_bus:
```c
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No direct violation in this fragment: the call passes lbus->bus_name to sysfs_open_bus, and this fragment does not invoke any <string.h> functions itself. A violation would only occur if sysfs_open_bus internally uses functions from <string.h> (e.g. strcpy, strncpy, memcpy) in a way that reads/writes beyond the bounds of the object pointed to by lbus->bus_name (for example, if lbus->bus_name is not a valid null-terminated string or is longer than the destination buffer used inside sysfs_open_bus).
